body_text.text: Due to space limitations, we have omitted the proofs from the body of the paper. They can be found in the extended version.
A language L is accepted by a standard non-deterministic finite-state automaton iff  for a unidirectional PIA  with the same number of states.
PI languages also contain non-regular languages, and even some non-context-free ones.
We conjecture that not all context-free language are PI languages; e.g, the Dyck language of two types of well-nested parentheses seems not to be PI.
Closure Properties. We provide a construction of suitable PIAs in the appendix to show the following.
From the construction used in the proof of the above theorem, we also obtain:
The universality and inclusion problems for PIAs are undecidable.
The goal of this section is to prove the following theorem.
We now characterize the notion of consecutive task words using trimmings.
The trimming of a task word is unique, and we denote it .
Now to (S2): as the limited memory of PIAs hinders the manipulation of task words with unbounded length and data values, we operate on their extremal strings instead.

Extremal strings are obtained from data abstractions by keeping only the maximal and minimal positions in each layer with respect to the tasks. We extend to them the notions of consecutive and completed.
We characterize satisfiability in terms of perfect completed task words.
As a corollary of Lemma 2 and Lemma 1, we get:
